quest_title: The general solution of tan\(\theta\) tan2\(\theta\) = 1 is: [IOE - 063]
explanation_txt: \(\tan \theta \tan 2 \theta = 1 \\ \Rightarrow \tan \theta \times \cfrac {2 \tan \theta}{1- \tan^2 \theta} = 1 \\ \Rightarrow 2 \tan^2 \theta = 1 - \tan^2 \theta \\ \Rightarrow 3 \tan^2 \theta = 1 \\ \Rightarrow \tan^2 \theta = \tan^2 \left( \cfrac{\pi}{6} \right) \\ \Rightarrow \theta = n \pi \pm \cfrac{\pi}{6} \\ \Rightarrow \theta = (6n \pm 1) \cfrac{\pi}{6} \)
question_plain_title: The general solution of tan tan2 = 1 is: [IOE - 063]
ans2_plain_text: (6n 1)
ans3_plain_text: (4n 1)

quest_title: The equation of latus rectum of a parabola is \(x + y = 8\) and the equation of the tangent at the vertex is \(x + y = 12\), then length of the latus rectum is:
explanation_txt:
The length of latus rectum is four times the distance between tangent at vertex and latus rectum.

(The tangent at vertex of \(y^2 = 4ax \) is \( x =0 \) and LR is \( x =a \), length of LR is 4a)

So, \( l = 4 \times \left| \cfrac{12-8}{\sqrt{1+1}} \right| = 8 \sqrt 2 \)

quest_title: If \(\sin ^{-1} x=\theta +\beta \) and \(\sin ^{-1} y=\theta -\beta ,\)then \(1+xy=\)
explanation_txt:
Obviously \(x=\sin \, (\theta +\beta )\) and \(y=\sin \, (\theta -\beta )\)

\[{\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} \, \, 1+xy=1+\sin \, (\theta +\beta )\sin \, (\theta -\beta )\]

\(=1+\sin ^{2} \theta -\sin ^{2} \beta \\ =\sin ^{2} \theta +\cos ^{2} \beta .\)

Velocity of coin relative to floor is zero so,

\(\mathrm{h}=\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{gt}^{2} \)
\(\mathrm{t}=\sqrt{\cfrac{2 \mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{g}}}=\sqrt{\cfrac{2 \times 2.5}{10}}=\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \mathrm{sec} \)

quest_title: The roots of the given equation \(2(a^{2} +b^{2} )x^{2} +2(a+b)x+1=0\) are
explanation_txt:
Given equation \[2(a^{2} +b^{2} )x^{2} +2(a+b)x+1=0\]

Let \(A=2(a^{2} +b^{2} ), B=2(a+b)\) and \(C=1\)

\[B^{2} -4AC=4(a^{2} +b^{2} +2ab)-4\, .2(a^{2} +b^{2} )\, 1\]

\[\Rightarrow B^{2} -4AC=-4(a-b)^{2} <0\]

Thus given equation has imaginary roots.

Thus given equation has imaginary roots.

A man starts walking from a point on the surface of earth (assumed smooth) and reaches diagonally opposite point. What is the work done by him

quest_title: A block of mass 10 kg is placed on a rough horizontal surface having coefficient of friction 0.5. If a horizontal force of 100 N is applied on it, the acceleration of block will be
explanation_txt:
Limiting force of friction

\(F_{f}=\mu R=0.5 \times 100=50 \mathrm{N}\)

Now, \(F-F_{f}=m a\)
or, \(a=\cfrac{100-50}{10}=\cfrac{50}{10}=5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

quest_title: How long will it take a sample of radioactive substance to decrease to 20% if its half life is 4 days?
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{\mathrm{N}}{\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{o}}}=\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\cfrac{t}{T_{1/2}}}\)
or, \(20 \%=\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\cfrac{t}{T_{1/2}}}\)
or, \(\ln 0.2=\cfrac{\mathrm{t}}{\mathrm{T}_{1 / 2}} \ln 0.5\)
or, \(\mathrm{t}=\mathrm{T}_{1 / 2} \cfrac{\ln 0.2}{\ln 0.5}\)

quest_title: A function \( f ( x ) = \left\{ \begin{array} { l l } { 1 + x , } & { x \leq 2 } \\ { 5 - x , } & { x > 2 } \end{array} \right. \) is
explanation_txt:
\[\lim _ { h \rightarrow 0 ^ { - } } 1 + ( 2 - h ) = 3 , \lim _ { h \rightarrow 0 ^ { + } } 5 - ( 2 + h ) = 3 , f ( 2 ) = 3 \]

Hence, continuous at x = 2.

\[R f ^ { \prime } ( x ) = \lim _ { h \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { 5 - ( 2 + h ) - 3 } { h } = - 1\]

\[L f ^ { \prime } ( x ) = \lim _ { h \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { 1 + ( 2 - h ) - 3 } { - h } = 1\]

\( \because R f ^ { \prime } ( x ) \neq L f ^ { \prime } ( x ) ; \therefore \) f is not differentiable at x = 2.
question_plain_title: A function is
explanation_plain_text:
Hence, continuous at x = 2.

f is not differentiable at x = 2.

quest_title: The position of particle changes from \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{r}_{1}}=(3 \hat{i}+2 \hat{j}-6 \hat{k})\)m to \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{r}_{2}}=(14 \hat{i}+13 \hat{\mathrm{j}}+9 \hat{\mathrm{k}})\)m under the action of force \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}}=(4 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\hat{\mathrm{j}}+3 \hat{\mathrm{k}})\)= N then word done will be
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{aligned} \overrightarrow{\mathrm{r}}=\overrightarrow{\mathrm{r}_{2}}-\overrightarrow{\mathrm{r}_{1}} &=(14 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+13 \hat{\mathrm{j}}+9 \hat{\mathrm{k}})-(3 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+2 \hat{\mathrm{j}}-6 \hat{\mathrm{k}}) \\ &=11 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+11 \hat{\mathrm{j}}+15 \hat{\mathrm{k}} \end{aligned}\)

\(\begin{aligned} W=\vec{F} \cdot \vec{S} &=(4 \hat{i}+\hat{j}+3 \hat{k}) \cdot(11 \hat{k}+11 \hat{j}+15 \hat{k}) \\ &=44+11+45=100 J \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: A ball \(\text{B}\)\({}_{1}\) of mass \(\text{m}\) moving with velocity \(\text{v}\)\({}_{1}\) collides head on with another ball \(\text{B}\)\({}_{2}\) of same mass at rest. The coefficient of restitution is \(\text{e}\) then ratio of velocities of ball after collision is
explanation_txt:
\(m v_{1}=m v^{\prime}+m v^{\prime \prime}\)
or, \(v^{\prime}+v^{\prime \prime}=v_{1}\) .........(1)

Again,

\(e=\cfrac{v^{\prime \prime}-v^{\prime}}{v_{1}}\)

or, \(\quad v^{\prime \prime}-v^{\prime}=e v_{1}\) ..........(2)

Adding (1) and (2),

\(2 v^{\prime \prime}=(1+e) v_{1}\)

or, \(v^{\prime \prime}=\cfrac{(1+e) v_{1}}{2}\)

From \((1)\),

\(v^{\prime}=v_{1}-\cfrac{(1+e) v_{1}}{2}=\cfrac{v_{1}(1-e)}{2}\)
\(\therefore \cfrac{v^{\prime \prime}}{v^{\prime}}=\cfrac{1+e}{1-e}\)

explanation_plain_text:

Adding (1) and (2),

or,

quest_title: The length of common chord of the circles \(( x - a ) ^ { 2 } + y ^ { 2 } = a ^ { 2 }\) and \(x ^ { 2 } + ( y - b ) ^ { 2 } = b ^ { 2 }\) is
explanation_txt:
The common chord is: \(( x - a ) ^ { 2 } + y ^ { 2 } - a ^ { 2 } = x ^ { 2 } + ( y - b ) ^ { 2 } - b ^ { 2 }\)

Or \( -2ax = -2by \)

Or \( ax - by = 0 \)

Length of common chord is given by:

\( L = 2 \sqrt { r _ { 1 } ^ { 2 } - p _ { 1 } ^ { 2 } } = 2 \sqrt { r _ { 2 } ^ { 2 } - p _ { 2 } ^ { 2 } } \)

where \(r_1\) and \(r_2\) are radii of given circles and \(p_1,p_2\) are the perpendicular distances from centres of circles to common chords.

Hence, \( L =2 \sqrt { a ^ { 2 } - \cfrac { a ^ { 4 } } { a ^ { 2 } + b ^ { 2 } } } = \cfrac { 2 a b } { \sqrt { a ^ { 2 } + b ^ { 2 } } } \)

\(\begin{array}{l}{=2 \mathrm{R} \times 50 \times \cfrac{3}{2}} \\ {=150 \mathrm{R}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: The angle between the tangents drawn from the origin to the parabola \(y ^ { 2 } = 4 a ( x - a )\) is
explanation_txt:
Any line through origin is \(y = m x\). Since it is a tangent to \(y ^ { 2 } = 4 a ( x - a )\), it will cut it in two coincident points.

Roots of \(m ^ { 2 } x ^ { 2 } - 4 a x + 4 a ^ { 2 } = 0\) are equal.

\(16 a ^ { 2 } - 16 a ^ { 2 } m ^ { 2 } = 0 \)

So, \(m = 1 , - 1\)

Product of slopes is -1. Hence the tangents are normal.

quest_title: Which of the elements occurs in allotropic forms ?
explanation_txt:
Different physical forms in which an element can exist are known as allotropes.

Allotropes of sulphur are Monoclinic, Rhombic, Colloidal, Plastic etc

quest_title: The remainder obtained by dividing \( 3x^3 - 4x^2 + 10 \) by \(x+7\) is:
explanation_txt:
Remainder theorem: The remainder when \( f(x) \) is divided by \(x-a\) is \(f(a)\), [ IF f(x) IS POLYNOMIAL]

So, the remainder is \( f(-7) = -1215 \)

quest_title: Rectangles are inscribed in a circle of radius \(r\). The dimensions of the rectangle for the maximum area are:
explanation_txt:
\(x=2 r \cos \theta\)
\(y=2 r \sin \theta\)

In \(\Delta {ABC}, \cos \theta=\cfrac{{x}}{2 {r}}\)
\(\sin \theta=\cfrac{{y}}{2 {r}}\)

Area of rectangle \(=x y=2 r \sin \theta .2 r \cos \theta\)
\(\quad=2 r^{2} \sin 2 \theta\) which is maximum when
\(\sin 2 \theta=1 \sin \cfrac{\pi}{2}\)
i.e. \(\theta=\cfrac{\pi}{4}\)
\(x=y=2 r \sin \left(\cfrac{\pi}{4}\right)=2 r \cdot \cfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=r \sqrt{2}\)

explanation_txt:

\(\quad\)\(\therefore \)\(\quad\)\(R\) = \(mg\) = \(60 \times \) 10 = 600 N
